item.title: 5 - Basics
item.description: Theorem 5.1.3 (Sequential Criterion for Continuity) A function $f : A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is continuous at $c \in A$ if and only if for every sequence $(x_n)$ in $A$ that converges to $c$, the sequence $(f(x_n))$ converges to $f(c)$. proof: Assume $f : A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is continuous at $c \in A$. Suppose sequence $(x_n)$ in $A$ converges to $c$. Let $\varepsilon > 0$ be given. By definition 5.1.1, there exists $\delta > 0$ such that for any $x \in A$ with $| x - c | < \delta$, $| f(x) - f(c) | < \varepsilon$.
